content:
Yes, that's correct. Socrates was put on trial and sentenced to death in Athens in 399 BCE, in part because of his method of questioning and his willingness to challenge the beliefs and values of those in power. The charges against him included impiety (not believing in the gods of the city) and corrupting the youth (encouraging young people to question authority and think for themselves).

Socrates' insistence on asking difficult questions and challenging the status quo made him unpopular with some of the powerful figures in Athens. At his trial, he refused to back down from his beliefs or compromise his principles, even when faced with the possibility of death. His commitment to his ideas and his refusal to compromise made him a martyr for intellectual freedom and the pursuit of truth.
